Award.AwardTitle: Modeling and Radiosonde Data Investigations of Turbulence and Mixing in the Vicinity of the Tropopause
Award.AbstractNarration:
The tropopause is the level of the atmosphere that can be thought of as a dividing line between the lower atmosphere (troposphere) and middle atmosphere (stratosphere). This level is relevant for several reasons, one of which is that it can be a turbulent region where aircraft fly. In this award, the research team will make use of a special set of weather balloon data and high-resolution numerical modeling to investigate turbulence in the tropopause region. Beyond aviation safety, the project is also relevant for understanding how water vapor and chemical constituents move from the troposphere to the stratosphere, which affects the global climate. A graduate student will also receive training under this award.

This work is aimed at answering questions about instability and turbulence in the vicinity of the tropopause. The two major goals of the project are to determine where atmospheric turbulence maximizes in relation to tropopause height and to derive estimates of effective turbulent mixing in the vicinity of the tropopause. The main tools that will be used include the US High Vertical Resolution Radiosonde Data (HVRRD) archive from 2005-on and numerical modeling using direct numerical simulations (DNS). The specific questions to be addressed include: 1) Why have some previous investigations of atmospheric turbulence found the maximum turbulence in the free atmosphere to be below the tropopause, while others have found the maximum to be above the tropopause? 2) How does the profile of atmospheric turbulence in the vicinity of the tropopause derived from Thorpe analysis of U.S. HVRRD vary from station to station? How does it depend on the underlying topography? Is there a systematic variation with latitude? Are there seasonal and diurnal variations? Can we explain these variations by gravity wave breaking or Kelvin-Helmholtz instability and different tropopause configurations? 3) How does the average turbulent mixing in the vicinity of the tropopause compare to the “effective mixing”, taking account of the presence of observed intermittent, thin, turbulent layers?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have compared the raw and processed U.S. high vertical-resolution radiosonde temperature data. The processed data have been subject to radiation corrections and smoothing. While the radiation corrections have been well documented, details of the smoothing used for the processed data are unavailable to us. We have tried to characterize the smoothing used in producing the processed data in this project and have found that the small-scale variability of the data is larger in the stratosphere than in the troposphere and are larger under daytime sunlit conditions than during nighttime darkness for both the raw and processed data. In addition, the small-scale variability and their daytime and nighttime differences are larger in raw data than processed data. As the vertical scale increases the geographical patterns of the variability over the contiguous US start resembling previously published gravity wave total energy patterns for both the raw and processed data in both the troposphere and stratosphere.

We have compared monthly time series and seasonally averaged turbulence intensity profiles at various stations and in various latitude bands using the processed radiosonde data. We have suggested that the noted discrepancy in the location of the maximum turbulence relative to the tropopause in the published literature is resolved if one examines our Thorpe analysis results as a function of latitude and season. In addition, we have argued that differences in the “observational windows” between the radar measured turbulence and Thorpe-derived turbulence contribute to resolving the discrepancy.

We have obtained the statistics of overturning events as a function of layer depth and altitude using the processed radiosonde for all the available US stations during 2005-2019. Such overturning event information is crucial to the calculation of effective turbulent mixing rates.

Finally, we have conducted high resolution numerical simulations of gravity wave encounters with tropopause for various idealized and more realistic background stratification profiles. Those simulations help shed light on wave propagation and turbulence generation near the tropopause.
